newsitem.title: BELGIUM: No large-scale Belgian tax cuts in 1998 - minister.
newsitem.headline: No large-scale Belgian tax cuts in 1998 - minister.

text.p: Belgium has taken adequate measures to bring down budget deficits and state debt and will undoubtedly meet the Maastricht Treaty's EMU criteria, but it is still too early for large-scale tax cuts, Budget Minister Herman Van Rompuy said.
"Economic growth will be too small in 1998 to present 'fun things'. There will hopefully be a chance in 1999," he told Belgian newspaper De Standaard in an interview published on Tuesday.
He quoted Belgian Planning Bureau figures putting 1998 growth at a moderate 2.6 percent.

The Belgian National Bank expects 1997 growth of two percent, while the Paris-based Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development forecasts 2.25 percent. The OECD foresees 2.5 percent growth in 1998.

Van Rompuy said the budget deficit as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product would be "just below 2.9 percent this year, with a little bit of luck." In 1996 the deficit/GDP ratio was 3.2 percent, he said, quoting National Bank figures.
Among the criteria for entry into Europe's single currency union, due to start in 1999, the Maastricht Treaty stipulates that a country's budget deficit must amount to no more than three percent.

"Belgium will meet the three percent criteria in any case. With as a curious consequence that nobody talks about the Belgian budget problem anymore. In the mean time the French and the Germans have a lot of trouble to reach 3.5 percent, even with a lot of creative accounting," Van Rompuy said.
